title: Focused Assessment with Sonography for Trauma (FAST)
description: Predicts presence of pericardial or intra-abdominal injury after penetrating or blunt trauma based on ultrasound findings.

parameters.name: pericardial_fluid
parameters.description: Presence of pericardial fluid on ultrasound

parameters.name: right_upper_quadrant_fluid
parameters.description: Presence of fluid in right upper quadrant (Morison's pouch) on ultrasound

parameters.name: left_upper_quadrant_fluid
parameters.description: Presence of fluid in left upper quadrant (splenorenal recess) on ultrasound

parameters.name: suprapubic_fluid
parameters.description: Presence of suprapubic fluid on ultrasound

result.name: fast_result
result.description: FAST examination result and clinical recommendation

ranges.interpretation: FAST negative. However, negative FAST does not exclude injury. Clinical correlation and consideration of additional imaging based on mechanism and clinical status is recommended.
Pericardial fluid detected. Emergent surgical intervention is recommended.
Intra-abdominal fluid detected in hemodynamically unstable patient. Emergent exploratory laparotomy is recommended.
Intra-abdominal fluid detected in hemodynamically stable patient. Cross-sectional imaging (CT scan) is recommended for further evaluation.
Equivocal FAST findings. Consider repeat FAST examination, clinical correlation, and/or additional imaging as indicated.

references: Rozycki GS, Ochsner MG, Jaffin JH, Champion HR. Prospective evaluation of surgeons' use of ultrasound in the evaluation of trauma patients. J Trauma. 1993 Apr;34(4):516-26; discussion 526-7.

Rozycki GS, Ballard RB, Feliciano DV, Schmidt JA, Pennington SD. Surgeon-performed ultrasound for the assessment of truncal injuries: lessons learned from 1540 patients. Ann Surg. 1998 Oct;228(4):557-67.

Rozycki GS, Ochsner MG, Schmidt JA, Frankel HL, Davis TP, Wang D, et al. A prospective study of surgeon-performed ultrasound as the primary adjuvant modality for injured patient assessment. J Trauma. 1995 Sep;39(3):492-8; discussion 498-500.
American College of Emergency Physicians. Emergency ultrasound guidelines. Ann Emerg Med. 2009 Apr;53(4):550-70.
formula: Assessment based on presence/absence of fluid in four anatomical regions: pericardium, right upper quadrant (Morison's pouch), left upper quadrant (splenorenal recess), and suprapubic region.
notes: FAST results alone should not dictate the decision to operate
Negative FAST does not exclude injury
Ultrasound is user dependent; clinicians should be cautious in interpretation
Sensitivities of abdominal and suprapubic views vary widely (22-98%)
In penetrating thoracic trauma, pericardial view sensitivity approaches 100%
Extended FAST (eFAST) includes bilateral thoracic views for pneumo- and hemothoraces
Hemodynamic stability assessment is crucial for management decisions
